His entire critique is worth the read, but one thing in particular stuck out to me: Apple, if it chooses to do so, will simply kill Playstation, Wii-U and xBox by introducing an open 30%-cut app/game ecosystem for Apple-TV. I already make a lot of money on iOS – I will be the first to write apps for Apple-TV when I can, and I know I’ll make money.

Message.Title: A worrying trend or a contrarian indicator?
Message.Msg: Leon Cooperman's Omega Advisors was far from the only big hedge fund to unload its Apple (AAPL) position in Q4. Joining Omega were Dan Loeb's Third Point, Thomas Steyer's Farallon Capital, Barry Rosenstein's Jana Partners, John Burbank's Passport Capital, and Eric Mindich's Elton Park Capital. On the other hand, David Einhorn's Greenlight Capital raised its stake to 1.3M shares from 1.1M and bought 275K call options ahead of its Prop. 2 suit (13F). Apple has historically been a hedge fund darling.

Topic.Title: Fear and Greed

Message.Msg: Yes. I have been retired since 2001 and enhance my retirement income by using this strategy. I find a stock that I like that pays a dividend. I wait until it is near its 52 week low and look for companies that have a good chance to rebound on any (anticipated news). After the stock goes up a little, I sell calls with a strike price that is higher than my purchase price. If the price goes down, I either buy the calls back or just let them expire and sell the calls again.

Topic.Title: no one is more bullish here than me....

Message.Msg: Sure they are shareholder friendly. Apple marches to the beat of their own drum and makes massive amounts of money. They have plans in place and they *do* turn a blind eye to investor sentiment ... as they should. You simply cannot, under ANY circumstance, allow Wall Street to disrupt your focus. As some already stated, just be patient. Apple's shareholder base is changing, and the purge is simply something they can do NOTHING about. Propping up the stock price by disrupting innovation, speeding up product launches, while risking quality, or any means of knee jerk, short-minded thinking will ultimately backfire. This company is run extremely well. The management team will continue to lead Apple to record products and I'm fully confident in the future release of existing and new products. The second half of this year will be amazing, and iTV and possibly China Mobile announcements will the stock at or near $700, once again. Be patient, folks. Apple's quiet and confident demeanor is something to take solace in, not bash and fret over.

Message.Title: Here's my feeling on what's going on with AAPL
Message.Msg: Newbie Cook took over from Jobs desperate to prove he's worthy. All that Jobs posthumous praise got to him. HE made a deal with devil (wall street) to give in to their dividend demand in return for hedge funds to take AAPL to stratosphere, thus establishing Cook's credentials. What Cookie didn't know that once you sell your soul to the devil, there's no going back. Now wall st came back with their own set of demands, ie first they make cheap plastic phones for the 3rd world and debase their brand for a tiny bit of profit. Cook protested and hedge funds pulled the rug underneath AAPL's feet. I think from hereon out Wall St will be running AAPL and Cook will have little to no control on the company's direction. Something that Jobs was too smart to realize and not give into.

Topic.Title: COOK, DO SOMETHING YOU SOB, SHAREHOLDERS HATE YOU

Message.Msg: Did you hate him during the February '12-April12 run? How about the run up to $705.00 run? Seems the start of this perfect storm is a result of the long term cap gains sell off. Add the big boys selling off after a great run up. As well as CNBCs champaign to slam the company/ analysts blindly speculating about upcoming releases. You need to remember its the analysts who talk daily on the speculative iTV. Not Cook, listen to the last conference call, the one thing Cook said was avoid listening to all the noise, AAPLs quarter was fantastic, they beat expectation, they banked another 17 billion. The only drawbacks were a slight revenue miss, a miscall on iMac release date, as well as the lack of an extra week that blew us all away last January. Cooks not dancing to the tune of all the analyts and media who lacks the patience of newly released products. As for the stockpile of cask in AAPLs hands, relax, with that amount of cash they could buy Disney and still have a comfy nest egg. They have so many great potentials with that kind old cash. Lets just wait and see ppl. Keep I'm mind the tortoise and the hair, just a li'l patience ppl. And stop listening to the media slant.

Message.Title: Most tech stocks near 52-week high, but AAPL near 52-week low
Message.Msg: COOK and Borad of Directors need to reflect on what has happened, They can't just keep talking about how things are - they need to excite investors by talking about the future and then delivering with super-sonic speed. Current stock price = utter lack of confidence in Cook's ability to preserve what Jobs accomplished, if not grow even further. His recent appearance suggests he is not up to the task. LIke to see the following: 1. Stock split to broaden ownership and to bring in retail investors. 2. Increase dividend by 10%. 3. Start 10% stock buyback. 4. Put remaining cash to work and earn more than close to zero percent - that's unacceptable. 5. Announce new major products, not just upgrades. Get out iWatch or iTV or whatever - can't work on them at leisurely pace. 6. Cook needs to talk more about future to excite investors - stop being so secretive, it's actually hurting the stock. Stop saying that he is not concerned about stock price - 30% decline while other tech stocks setting record highs is not an insignificant event. It's a total loss of confidence, so can't just dismiss it.

Message.Msg: It's like saying, i made a million last year, when the gov't took half and you only made 550k. Topic.Title: How many people will come back even if Apple come up with new product, after what they are putting us through?

Message.Msg: The media HAS been beating up on them ..... but i guess it's been drumming into your mind as well, because they're NOT "the most hated" company. That is truly a warped viewpoint .... and again, your first assertion is to play there. Market forces have been at work to draw the stock price down, initially because of a highly over-bought and owned condition with many investment firms, but more recently, because of this backdrop of negative media sentiment, which i believe to an extent is covert behind-the-scenes manipulating by various money players trying to get in at cheaper prices. So far, it's been working, and will probably continue to be for a while. Ironically, I bet Goldman is partly at-play here, because of their recent talking-up of the stock, which is very typical of them. But at any rate, this stock-churning will continue, probably into mid-late spring, and will move the price down to 370-400. Be watching for that final bottom, because THEN is where to make your next move for a Long position(s).

Message.Title: Nasdaq Proposes Earlier Start to U.S. Pre-Market Stock Trading
Message.Msg: Nasdaq OMX Group Inc., the second- biggest U.S. exchange operator, said it plans to start pre- market stock trading earlier in the day. Trading will begin at 4 a.m. New York time, instead of 7 a.m., according to a Feb. 12 statement. The change will happen no earlier than March 18, subject to approval by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. Nasdaq is seeking to attract more trading after U.S. equity volume declined for a third straight year in 2012. The exchange is expanding into derivatives, setting up a new London-based market and buying a 25 percent stake in a Dutch alternative trading system focused on stocks and equity derivatives. Average daily volume for equities listed on all U.S. exchanges was 6.07 billion shares in the fourth quarter, 18 percent less than a year earlier, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.
